page.title: 17Cramlington:Customs
page.content: Local traditions and customs are now little different to those of any modern town, but one or two odd ones still remain. An interesting one is the making of a{Christening}when a child is baptised. This is a bag containing salt, sugar, cake, silver coins and a toy.It is given to the first child of the opposite sex to the baby seen on the way to church. Some older people still make a{Garland}at Christmas. This is made of two hoops joined at right angles, and decorated with ribbons and tinsel. These were common before Christmas trees came into use. At weddings in the town a Hoy-oot can still sometimes happen. When the couple drive away from the church, they throw a handful of small coins from their car for watching children to pick up.Quite dangerous! Klondyke F.S.
